author: By Amelia Nierenberg
title: Your Monday Briefing: North Korea’s Growing Outbreak
description: Plus India bans most wheat exports and South Korea amends surgery laws.
content: State media reported 21 new deaths and a huge jump in suspected coronavirus cases on Saturday, as North Korea struggled to contain its first reported outbreak.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eduardo Medina
title: 1 Dead and 4 Are Critically Injured in California Church Shooting
description: A total of six people were shot before congregants overpowered the gunman and hogtied him at a church in Laguna Woods, Calif., the authorities said. A motive was still unclear.
content: A gunman who opened fire inside a Southern California church on Sunday, killing one person and critically wounding four others, was overpowered by congregants who then hogtied him, preventing further bloodshed, the authorities said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marc Tracy
title: How Hollywood and the Media Fueled the Political Rise of J.D. Vance
description: “Hillbilly Elegy,” a best-selling memoir that became a star-studded film, raised the profile of the onetime “Never Trump guy” who won an Ohio primary with the help of the former president.
content: Members of New York’s smart set gathered on a warm Thursday evening in the early summer of 2016 at the ornately wallpapered apartment of two Yale Law School professors in the elegant Ansonia building on Manhattan’s Upper West Side to toast a Marine Corps veteran, venture capitalist and first-time author named J.D. Vance.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Hubbard, Hwaida Saad and Asmaa al-Omar
title: After Lebanon’s Collapse, Can an Election Fix the Country?
description: On Sunday, Lebanese voters got their first chance to pass judgment on lawmakers since the economy fell apart. Few expect things to improve.
content: BEIRUT, Lebanon — After years abroad working as a school administrator, Anahid Jobanian returned to Lebanon to live off her savings for a simple retirement.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amanda Holpuch
title: Good Samaritans Rushed Into Traffic to Save Driver, Video Shows
description: A group of strangers who saved an unconscious Florida driver on May 5 reunited on Friday after a video of the dramatic rescue circulated online.
content: Laurie Rabyor can remember May 5 only in flashes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Edward Dolnick
title: Exploration at the Edge of Disaster
description: “River of the Gods” is a fast-paced tale of the absurdly dangerous quest by two friends turned enemies to solve the geographic riddle of their era.
content: The first law of travelers’ tales is simply put: the worse, the better. No reader wants to hear of well-made plans or sunsets that paint the sky in glorious reds and purples. Give us a ship trapped in the ice or desperate wanderers sitting down to a meal of frozen boot. Better yet, give us two Victorian rivals in East Africa, supposed colleagues who were consumed with hate for each other, weak from fever, half-starved and half-blind but nonetheless obsessed with solving a mystery that had mocked the world for 2,000 years.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David W. Chen
title: They Treated Their Sports Like a Job. They Wish the N.C.A.A. Had, Too.
description: A Supreme Court ruling and changes in college sports have given momentum to a lawsuit accusing the N.C.A.A. of violating federal minimum-wage laws by refusing to pay athletes like employees.
content: Tamara Statman may have had a student ID card during her four years playing softball at the University of Arizona, but she sometimes wondered if it should have read “Employee” instead.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maria Cramer, Christine Hauser and Livia Albeck-Ripka
title: Facing Higher Grocery Prices, Shoppers Change Habits
description: They’re store-hopping, cutting back on expensive items and using more coupons. Plying the meat counter staff with homemade banana bread for favors is not out of the question.
content: Susan Pollack, a property manager who was shopping one afternoon last week at a Costco in Marina del Rey, Calif., said she was startled that the price of a bulk pack of toilet paper had surged from $17 to $25.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexandra E. Petri
title: What we know about how the Buffalo shooting unfolded.
description: The gunman drove for hours to the Tops supermarket. He left a trail of bodies in the aisles and parking lot, apparently broadcasting his attack.
content: The shooting began in the parking lot. At about 2:30 p.m. on Saturday, after driving from hours away, a heavily armed man appeared outside a Tops supermarket. He was wearing tactical gear and body armor, with a video camera fixed to his helmet. He was carrying an assault weapon, with an anti-Black slur written on the barrel.
source.name: The New York Times

title: ‘My Father and I Decided We Should Try to Honor Her Wishes’
description: A Fifth Avenue farewell, eating nachos in the rain and more reader tales of New York City in this week’s Metropolitan Diary.
content: Dear Diary:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eduardo Medina
title: Ex-Nurse Convicted in Fatal Medication Error Gets Probation
description: RaDonda Vaught, a former nurse at Vanderbilt University Medical Center in Tennessee, said at her sentencing, “‘I’m sorry’ doesn’t seem like enough.”
content: A former nurse whose medication error killed a patient in Tennessee was sentenced to three years of probation on Friday, ending a case that had prompted concern among health care workers fearful that medical mistakes will be criminalized.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michelle Cottle
title: Donald Trump’s Faith in Celebrity Could Finally Backfire
description: Mr. Trump is putting his faith in the political value of celebrity to its purest test yet.
content: “His show is great. He’s on that screen. He’s in the bedrooms of all those women telling them good and bad.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Abdi Latif Dahir and Malin Fezehai
title: Somalia Elects New President, but Terrorists Hold True Power
description: The militants of Al Shabab collect taxes, decide court cases and control the streets. Somalis ask, will a new government even matter?
content: MOGADISHU, Somalia — In a fortified tent guarded by peacekeeping forces, hundreds of lawmakers elected a new president in Somalia on Sunday, capping a violent election season that threatened to push the Horn of Africa nation toward a breakdown.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Pamela Paul
title: Let Actors Act
description: Good performers are able to find a way to portray people who are not like themselves.
content: Adrian Lester, a British actor from Birmingham and the son of two immigrants from Jamaica, was nominated last week for a Tony Award for his performance in “The Lehman Trilogy” as Emanuel Lehman, one of the German-born Jewish founders of the fallen investment behemoth Lehman Brothers. Lester, like the other actors in the three-man play, takes on several parts, including female characters and at one point, a thumb-sucking toddler.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Denny Lee
title: Everything, Embellished, All at Once
description: Best looks from Spencer Sweeney’s art opening, the New York City Ballet gala and Variety’s Power of Women ceremony.
content: Former bad boys of New York’s downtown art scene spent last Sunday in the polo fields of Greenwich, Conn., where the Brant Foundation Art Study Center held a pared-back opening for Spencer Sweeney, the artist, D.J. and party ringleader. Instead of a lavish affair with spit-roasted lamb, artists like Dan Colen, Nate Lowman and Tabboo! had to chase down trays of canapés.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: May 15, 2022
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Sunday, May 15, 2022.
content: An article on Sunday about five men who were wrongly convicted of murder and how they banded together to get out of prison misidentified the television studio that is to produce “The Sing Sing Chronicles.” It is NBC News Studios, not NBC Studios.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Damien Cave
title: How Australia Saved Thousands of Lives While Covid Killed a Million Americans
description: The United States and Australia share similar demographics, but their pandemic death rates point to very different cultures of trust.
content: MELBOURNE, Australia — If the United States had the same Covid death rate as Australia, about 900,000 lives would have been saved. The Texas grandmother who made the perfect pumpkin pie might still be baking. The Red Sox-loving husband who ran marathons before Covid might still be cheering at Fenway Park.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Penelope Green
title: Larry Woiwode, Who Wrote of Family, Faith and Rural Life, Dies at 80
description: Raised in North Dakota and rural Illinois, he was a literary star in New York City in the 1970s. But he left the limelight to raise a family on a North Dakota farm.
content: Larry Woiwode, the author of lyrical, expansive novels, short stories, poems and essays, mostly planted in the American West, that explored the power of place, family ties and faith, spiritual and otherwise, died on April 28 in Bismarck, N.D. He was 80.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stanley Reed
title: Saudi Aramco cashes in on rising oil prices as profit jumps 80 percent.
description: The national oil company of Saudi Arabia said quarterly income reached nearly $40 billion, reflecting volatile energy markets.
content: Saudi Aramco, the national oil company of Saudi Arabia, reported on Sunday net income of $39.5 billion for the first quarter of 2022, a jump of about 80 percent from the same period a year earlier, largely reflecting higher oil prices.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mihir Zaveri, Emma Bubola and Ali Watkins
title: ‘All These Innocent Lives’: These Were the Victims in the Buffalo Attack
description: Friends and relatives shared remembrances of the people killed in the massacre, including a security guard who returned fire and shoppers running routine errands.
content: During his 30 years as a Buffalo police officer, Aaron Salter Jr. earned a reputation for bravery, with more than one of his exploits recorded in the local newspaper, The Buffalo News. He once chased down an arsonist, the newspaper reported, and on another occasion he faced down a burglar armed with a shotgun.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jack Ewing
title: The Tesla Effect: Snowmobiles, Boats and Mowers Go Electric
description: They’re quieter and better for the climate. But snow and water create new technological challenges for designers.
content: STOWE, Vt. — Snowmobiles are part of the winter soundtrack in this part of Vermont, at their worst shattering the stillness of the forest like motorcycles on skis. But the motorized sleds bouncing along a wooded mountain trail in February were silent except for the whoosh of metal runners on snow.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Edward Wong and Anatoly Kurmanaev
title: NATO Leaders Say They Will Speed Finland and Sweden Membership Bids
description: In another setback for Moscow, top officials from alliance nations met over the weekend in Berlin to discuss admitting Finland and Sweden and supporting Ukraine.
content: BERLIN — The head of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization said Sunday that the security bloc would grant fast-track membership to Sweden and Finland, raising the pressure on Vladimir V. Putin, who justified his invasion of Ukraine by what he cast as the need to keep the military alliance away from Russia’s borders.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Waldstein
title: The Loneliest Team in Baseball
description: With the Oakland Athletics having gutted their roster and flirted with Las Vegas, their once-loyal fans appear to be in revolt.
content: OAKLAND, Calif. — On one quiet night earlier this month, fewer than 3,000 fans attended an Athletics game. It was so vacant and tranquil at the bulky, old coliseum that the visiting Tampa Bay Rays players could hear the crisp enunciation of every taunt flung their way.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Times Insider Staff
title: Remembering One in One Million
description: As the United States marks one million Covid-19 deaths, Times journalists reflect on the one story or moment from the pandemic that will stay with them forever.
content: Covid-19 has taken the lives of nearly one million people in the United States. A number like that is difficult to comprehend. One million individuals — mothers, fathers, siblings, grandparents, children, friends — as represented by dots on a new Times map, make up that staggering, sobering statistic. We asked Times journalists who have covered the pandemic to share one moment that changed their approach to reporting — or one story they will never forget. Read their responses below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ashley Southall, Chelsia Rose Marcius and Andy Newman
title: Before the Massacre, Erratic Behavior and a Chilling Threat
description: Payton Gendron was sent for a psychiatric evaluation when he was still in high school but soon fell off investigators’ radar.
content: Last spring, as the end of the academic year approached at Susquehanna Valley High School outside Binghamton, N.Y., students were asked for a school project about their plans after graduation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jazmine Ulloa
title: In Madison Cawthorn’s District, Strong Opinions of Him, For and Against
description: The right-wing firebrand is counting on Republican primary voters to look past his bad press. Opponents are counting on them to lose patience with him.
content: HENDERSONVILLE, N.C. — When Representative Madison Cawthorn’s name comes up in this city of 14,000, where he was born and raised and it is not difficult to bump into someone who knew him from his home-schooling days, there tends to be a visceral reaction.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zachary Woolfe
title: Review: After 36 Years, a Malcolm X Opera Sings to the Future
description: Anthony Davis’s “X” has stretches of incantation that, in person, turn it into something like a sacred rite.
content: DETROIT — “When a man is lost,” sings Betty Shabazz, Malcolm X’s wife, “does the sky bleed for him, or does the sunset ignore his tears?”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: What’s Going On in This Picture? | May 16, 2022
description: Look closely at this image, stripped of its caption, and join the moderated conversation about what you and other students see.
content: 1. After looking closely at the image above (or at the full-size image), think about these three questions:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Schuessler
title: We, the Writers? A Global Literary Congress Meets in New York
description: Authors from 30 countries held an “emergency” meeting at the United Nations to address the multiple crises of the moment — and whether stories can help.
content: The Russian invasion of Ukraine has evoked a back-to-the-future Cold War frisson, in culture as much as politics.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Mann
title: A Total Lunar Eclipse in Prime-Time
description: On Sunday night, Earth’s shadow will fall over the moon and make our natural satellite turn blood red.
content: Finally a good reason to stay up on Sunday night: A total lunar eclipse.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Baker
title: A Fracture in Idaho’s G.O.P. as the Far Right Seeks Control
description: Ahead of a primary vote, traditional Republicans are raising alarm about the future of the party, warning about the growing strength of militia members, racists and the John Birch Society.
content: BONNERS FERRY, Idaho — At a school gymnasium in northern Idaho, Lt. Gov. Janice McGeachin regaled a crowd with stories of her feuds with the current governor, a fellow Republican, including the time when he briefly left the state and she issued a mutinous but short-lived ban on coronavirus mask mandates.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Johanna Lemola and Steven Erlanger
title: Finland’s president talks of ‘a new era’ as he launches its bid to join NATO.
description: The Nordic nation would end decades of nonalignment if, as widely expected, it is admitted to the alliance.
content: HELSINKI, Finland — Finland’s government announced on Sunday that it would apply for membership in NATO, a move that would end decades of strategic nonalignment and pave the way for one of the most significant expansions of the Western military alliance in years.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rachel Fabi
title: Whenever One Wishes
description: Lynn Lempel’s puzzle will make you simile.
content: Programming note: We are happy to announce that Wordplay will also appear in the print edition of The New York Times on Page A2 on alternating Mondays. This will be the first exposure to the crossword column (and the Crossword) for some readers, so we will be explaining some beginners’ solver concepts and may experiment with the format of the column on those days. We will also include more behind-the-scenes information, so you can look forward to that. Thank you — as always — for reading and for your patience!
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher F. Schuetze
title: In a Setback for Scholz, Conservatives Keep Western State in Germany
description: Chancellor Olaf Scholz’s Social Democrats scored record-low votes in the first major electoral test he has faced since taking office.
content: BERLIN — Chancellor Olaf Scholz’s Social Democrats, in a regional election overshadowed by the war in Ukraine, scored record-low vote percentages on Sunday as Germany’s most populous state went to the polls.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Susan Burton
title: When It Comes to Labels, Selma Blair Will Write Her Own
description: In her memoir, “Mean Baby,” the actor opens up about daily life with multiple sclerosis and the different identities she has juggled all her life.
content: Growing up, Selma Blair had the mystical experience common to adolescent girls who want to be writers: an encounter with Joan Didion. “It was as if she were speaking straight to me,” Blair writes of discovering Didion’s work in high school.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Steven Erlanger and Christina Anderson
title: Sweden’s governing party says it will vote in favor of joining NATO.
description: The announcement was a shift for the Social Democratic Party, which has supported Swedish neutrality since before the collapse of the Soviet Union.
content: Sweden’s governing Social Democratic Party announced on Sunday that it would vote in favor of joining NATO, all but guaranteeing that the Nordic nation would end 200 years of neutrality and seek membership in the powerful Western military alliance.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zachary Woolfe
title: Review: ‘Hamlet’ Boldly Engulfs the Metropolitan Opera
description: Brett Dean and Matthew Jocelyn’s adaptation of the classic play is both traditional and innovative, elegant and passionate.
content: An opera composer would need the epic gifts and epic gall of a Richard Wagner to consider an adaptation of “Hamlet” and think: “Yup, I’ve got this.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher Clarey
title: What the Italian Open Is Foretelling About the French Open
description: Though at opposite poles of their careers, the top singles players, Iga Swiatek and Novak Djokovic, both cruised to titles in Rome and are looking strong heading into Paris.
content: ROME — We will soon find out how much of what happened Sunday at the Italian Open was foreshadowing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gary Phillips
title: Proving They Are Human, Mets Lose Their First Series of 2022
description: Splitting a series was the worst the Mets had done before the Mariners came to town for three games.
content: The Mets had not lost a series all season, but that streak sailed when the Seattle Mariners closed out a teeter-totter affair Sunday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isaac Aronow and Doug Mennella
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: SUNDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Glueck
title: Fetterman Recovering After Stroke Before His Senate Primary
description: John Fetterman, the Pennsylvania lieutenant governor who is running for the state’s Democratic Senate nomination, canceled events on Friday, Saturday and Sunday.
content: Lt. Gov. John Fetterman of Pennsylvania, the front-runner for his state’s Democratic Senate nomination, said on Sunday that he had had a stroke on Friday and was recovering.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Glenn Thrush and Emily Cochrane
title: Liberals, blocked on gun control, call for a new domestic terror law after the shooting.
description: On Sunday, Nancy Pelosi vowed to pass a bill that would increase information sharing to detect and deter extremist violence.
content: Democrats are vowing to push through domestic terrorism legislation to improve intelligence sharing and coordination between law enforcement agencies following the mass shooting in Buffalo — despite growing Republican opposition that could scuttle even those modest efforts.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Azi Paybarah
title: Kathy Barnette Says She ‘Can’t Provide a Lot of Context’ for Her Anti-Islamic Tweets
description: Her sudden rise in the Pennsylvania Senate primary has some Republicans worried about her prospects in November.
content: Kathy Barnette, a Republican Senate candidate in Pennsylvania who has climbed in the polls against two big-spending rivals, on Sunday sought to downplay her past Islamophobic messages on social media, telling a Fox News host that some of them were “not even full thoughts,” nor “even full sentences” but rather, prompts intended to facilitate a conversation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caity Weaver, Jack D'Isidoro, Aaron Esposito, John Woo, Dan Powell and David Mason
title: The Sunday Read: ‘I Lived the #VanLife. It Wasn’t Pretty.’
description: The writer Caity Weaver’s pursuit of the manifest destiny of the millennial generation ended up looking better in the photos.
content: The Times journalist Caity Weaver was tasked by her editor to go on an adventure: With an old college friend she would spend a week in California, living out of a converted camper van, in pursuit of the aesthetic fantasy known as #VanLife.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: 10 Shot Dead at Grocery in Buffalo; Attack Called a Hate Crime
description: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, May 15, 2022.
content: “It was a straight up racially motivated hate crime.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tish Harrison Warren
title: America Has a Scorn Problem
description: Too many of us think people with different opinions are not just wrong, but bad.
content: In the Bible’s Book of Luke, there’s a parable about a religious person, who has all the right opinions, and a tax collector, who is culturally despised. To paraphrase the religious person, he prays, “Thank you, God, that I’m not like those others, the immoral people.” But the tax collector beats his chest in sorrow and prays for God’s mercy. The parable is about the need for humility. The “sinner,” the tax collector, not the religious person, turns out to be the righteous one. Luke tells us that Jesus told this parable “to some who had great confidence in their own righteousness and scorned everyone else.” That appears to be a lot of us in 21st-century America.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Evan Easterling
title: The Reds Take a Big Risk, and Get a Loss for Their Trouble
description: For just the sixth time since 1901, a team allowed no hits and lost. In the Reds’ attempt at history, they allowed Hunter Greene, a rookie, to throw 118 pitches.
content: The Cincinnati Reds accomplished a baseball rarity Sunday by losing despite conceding no hits.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anton Troianovski and Marc Santora
title: Growing evidence of a military disaster on the Donets pierces a pro-Russian bubble.
description: As the news of the losses at the river crossing started to spread, some Russian bloggers did not hold back in their criticism of what they said was incompetent leadership.
content: The destruction wreaked on a Russian battalion as it tried to cross a river in northeastern Ukraine last week is emerging as among the deadliest engagements of the war, with estimates based on publicly available evidence now suggesting that well over 400 Russian soldiers were killed or wounded.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dave Itzkoff
title: ‘S.N.L.’ Takes on the Trial of Johnny Depp and Amber Heard
description: In an episode hosted by Selena Gomez, “Saturday Night Live” tried to distract itself from a dire news week with a celebrity lawsuit and whoopee cushions.
content: After a particularly challenging week of news events, “Saturday Night Live” took refuge in the defamation trial between Johnny Depp and Amber Heard.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By C. J. Hughes
title: Homes That Sold for Around $1 Million
description: Recent residential sales in New York City and the region.
content: Each week, our survey of recent residential sales in New York City and the surrounding region focuses on homes that sold around a certain price point, allowing you to compare single-family homes, condos and co-ops in different locales.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jane L. Levere
title: Business Travel Resumes, Though Not at Its Former Pace
description: Domestic travel has returned faster than international. And some destinations like Las Vegas are rebounding more quickly than big cities like New York.
content: Business travel appears to be returning, albeit unevenly, after all but disappearing for most of the pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesse Wegman
title: Justice Thomas Should Take a Long Look in the Mirror
description: If Justice Thomas is genuinely concerned about the eroding faith in his own institution, the first thing he can do is look in the mirror.
content: Thanks to the unparalleled position of power he has held for three decades, Supreme Court Justice Clarence Thomas — perhaps the most distinctive voice in an institution that has the final say over many of the nation’s most fraught debates — has long enjoyed the luxury of knowing that 330 million Americans are bound to listen to him. The question is, does he ever listen to himself?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: Mass Shooting in Buffalo
description: A massacre at a Buffalo supermarket was the deadliest in the U.S. this year.
content: Follow our live coverage of the mass shooting in Buffalo.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeffrey Gettleman and Cristian Movila
title: A Mini-Russia Gets Squeezed by War
description: The self-declared republic of Transnistria, on the Ukraine border, has been steered by Moscow for decades. During a rare visit, a reporter and photographer get an inside look into how it operates, and hear from Transnistrians their fears of war.
content: TIRASPOL, TRANSNISTRIA — At the Back in the U.S.S.R. cafe, it is like the Soviet Union never collapsed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Scott Cacciola
title: Celtics Dominate Bucks in Game 7 Win
description: Boston, with a surprise 27 points from Grant Williams, led by as many as 28. The Celtics will face the Miami Heat in the Eastern Conference finals.
content: BOSTON — It was no secret that Grant Williams was hesitating when he had open looks from the 3-point arc. The Milwaukee Bucks were offering him acres of real estate on Sunday afternoon, but Williams had reached the point, after a few early misses, when he was questioning himself. Doubt had crept in. His Celtics teammates told him to knock it off.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Claire Berlinski
title: The Memoir That Exposed a Family’s Secrets. And a Society’s.
description: A best seller in France, Camille Kouchner’s “The Familia Grande” is an indictment of incest that started a national reckoning.
content: It is hard to write a book about incest that is neither grotesque nor lurid, even more so when the family in question is famous, wealthy and powerful. Camille Kouchner’s memoir was a sensation in France for its unsparing portrait of gauche caviar, a sociological class with a distinct ideological heritage. Free of voyeurism and elegantly written, “The Familia Grande” is also an artistic success.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Motoko Rich and Hisako Ueno
title: Katsumoto Saotome, Who Preserved Stories of Tokyo Firebombing, Dies at 90
description: He compiled six books of survivors’ recollections of the 1945 attack. He also founded (without government support) a memorial museum.
content: TOKYO — Katsumoto Saotome, a novelist who lived through the brutal American firebombing of Tokyo during World War II and worked relentlessly to preserve the memories of survivors in published accounts and at a museum he founded, died on Tuesday in Saitama, Japan, a suburb of Tokyo. He was 90.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charlie Savage
title: Trump-Era Prosecutor’s Case Against Democratic-Linked Lawyer Goes to Trial
description: The first case developed by the special counsel, John Durham, involves a lawyer who is accused of lying when he shared a tip with the F.B.I. about possible links between Donald J. Trump and Russia.
content: WASHINGTON — When the Trump administration assigned a prosecutor in 2019 to scour the Russia investigation for any wrongdoing, President Donald J. Trump stoked expectations among his supporters that the inquiry would find a “deep state” conspiracy against him.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anushka Patil
title: Gunman targeted Black neighborhood shaped by decades of segregation.
description: In an online manifesto, the suspected gunman said he opened fire at Tops supermarket because it served a mostly Black neighborhood.
content: The high concentration of Black residents on Buffalo’s East Side — which the suspect in Saturday’s mass shooting said was his reason for targeting the area — is a direct result of decades of segregation and systemic racism, researchers have consistently found.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chris Cameron, Emily Cochrane and Glenn Thrush
title: Washington officials condemn white supremacist ideology and its ties to the far right.
description: Democratic and Republican lawmakers condemned the mass shooting in Buffalo and criticized political speech that they say encourages white supremacy.
content: Washington officials condemned the mass shooting in Buffalo and the racist motivations behind the attack, with Democrats and at least one retiring Republican criticizing political speech that they said encourages white supremacy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marie Solis
title: The Week in Business: Crypto’s ‘Death Spiral’
description: Elon Musk said he was putting his Twitter purchase “temporarily on hold.” Prices continued to climb last month, and the financial markets had another losing week.
content: In what some are calling a “death spiral,” the value of a number of digital currencies plunged last week, rattling investors’ faith in crypto markets. The implosion was particularly shattering for TerraUSD, or UST, which is called a stablecoin, meaning that it is pegged to a stable asset and should not fluctuate in price. But fluctuate it did: A big sell-off in a sister cryptocurrency sent UST to a low of 11 cents on Friday as Luna, a token closely tied to UST, cratered to $0. Bitcoin has been falling along with the Nasdaq, a benchmark that’s weighted toward technology stocks, making an investment in cryptocurrency just as risky as any other tech stock. The  crash drives home an unpleasant reality for investors — that an asset they hoped would be transformative has not fulfilled its promise.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Life in Mini-Russia
description: Transnistria is a country that doesn’t exist. It’s a breakaway republic, backed by Russia, recognized by no major nation. Our correspondent was able to make a rare visit earlier this month.
content: Transnistria is a country that doesn’t exist. It’s a breakaway republic, backed by Russia, recognized by no major nation. Our correspondent was able to make a rare visit earlier this month.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: Buffalo Community Holds a Vigil for Mass Shooting Victims
description: Community members gathered for a vigil outside the Tops supermarket in Buffalo to commemorate victims of the attack.
content: Community members gathered for a vigil outside the Tops supermarket in Buffalo to commemorate victims of the attack.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Sifton
title: What to Cook This Week
description: Flexible, shoulder-season recipes for roasted potato salad, white bean primavera, Korean cheeseburgers and more.
content: Good morning. It’s shoulder season where I stay — chill mornings giving way to warm afternoons, a string of decent weather followed by cold and rain — and I find I’m cooking to bridge the divide. That has its pleasures.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Abortions, Before and After Roe v. Wade
description: Readers recall abortions after miscarriages, rape and fetal abnormalities, and an obstetrician and adoptive parent tell their stories. Also: An abortion fund.
content: This is the second in a two-part series of personal stories from readers.
source.name: The New York Times
